stem: A 15-year-old client is 6 hours post-reduction of a tibial fracture with a plaster cast. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client is a 15-year-old male, 6 hours post-reduction and casting of a tibial fracture, experiencing severe pain unrelieved by opioid analgesics.
Background: The client underwent closed reduction and application of a plaster cast following a tibial fracture sustained in a sports-related injury. Pain management includes IV morphine administered per protocol.
Assessment: At 14:00, the client reports persistent, excruciating pain rated 10/10 despite morphine administration. Neurovascular assessment reveals pain with passive extension of toes, paresthesia in the toes, tense and shiny skin around the cast. Pulses are 2+ and present. Vital signs are stable.
Recommendation: Request immediate orthopedic surgical consult for evaluation of acute compartment syndrome and possible fasciotomy.

tabs.content: Initial X-ray confirmed tibial fracture. Post-reduction films not available.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Morphine 4mg IV q2hr PRN pain. Last dose given at 13:30.

actionOptions.text: Loosen or cut the restrictive dressing or cast
Maintain the affected limb at the level of the heart
Elevate the limb above the level of the heart
Apply ice packs and maintain high-pressure compression

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs and symptoms indicative of Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2). The hallmark sign is pain out of proportion to the injury, especially with passive motion. The 'pins and needles' sensation (paresthesia), tense/shiny skin, and a normal pulse are also consistent with this condition. The priority nursing actions are to alleviate external pressure by loosening or cutting the cast (a1) to improve circulation and maintaining the affected limb at the level of the heart (a2) to optimize arterial perfusion. Elevating the limb (a3) would further compromise arterial blood flow. Monitoring neurovascular status using the 6 Ps (p1) and assessing intracompartmental pressures (p2) are crucial for evaluating the severity and progression of the syndrome.
clinicalPearls: The 6 Ps: Pain, Paresthesia, Pallor, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia.
PARALYSIS and PULSELESSNESS are LATE signs. If you wait for them, the limb is likely dead.
Fasciotomy is the definitive surgical treatment.

questionTrap.trap: Elevating the leg for compartment syndrome.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Elevation is for SWELLING/EDEMA (Veins). Level-with-heart is for ISCHEMIA (Arteries). Compartment syndrome is an arterial/perfusion issue; do not elevate.
